title: (x) Monday Movie Madness - "Lucky Luke" poster - Sin City fan font {Lex}
content:
I don’t need Lucky Luke, just the credits. These brush capitals are very similar to the [Sin City](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734/http:/www.impawards.com/2005/sin_city_ver9.html) logo, originally designed by Frank Miller’s brother. This could be a fan font, but I hope it’s a quality design.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734im_/http:/typophile.com/files/lucky-luke_unknown_5059.jpg)
author: Bald Condensed

comments.content:
The brush is [Sin City](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734/http:/www.dafont.com/font.php?file=sin_city&page=1&nb_ppp_old=10&text=UN+FILM+DE+JAMES+HUTH&nb_ppp=10&psize=m&classt=alpha) based on the comic book logo (I’d recognize that ’S’ anywhere).

- Lex
D’oh. Could’ve found that one myself. Unlinkable though, as its design is ripped off; not original. :^/

They’re making a Lucky Luke film?! That’d be cool! They were some of my favourite comics as a kid. My Dad had a bunch in French that he used to read/translate for me, and when I started to learn French in High School, I’d try to read them myself, and watch how I got better over time.

Apparently it was released in [November 2009 in the US](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734/http:/www.imdb.com/title/tt1235536/releaseinfo), but no news on the Australian front.

Personally I think the best comics for learning French are [Asterix et Obelix](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734/http:/www.asterix.com/index.html.en), because the writing is (was) so incredibly clever and funny.

Well, they’ve already made a few Lucky Luke films:  
 [http://www.imdb.com/character/ch0027538/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100108184734/http:/www.imdb.com/character/ch0027538/ "http://www.imdb.com/character/ch0027538/")

I searched Dafont looking for this, but why this was under Script\>Various and not Script\>Brush is a mystery to me. Way to go Lex.

- Mike Yanega

Certainly agree with you there, Yves, and my Dad had a bunch of those in French as well. He lived in France for a few years before I was born and built up quite a collection of Asterix comics. Tintin too. And yes, I can’t believe how well they were translated into English. The names – Getafix, Unhygenix, Fulliautomatix, Vitalstatistix, etc, etc – are particularly memorable.

Riccardo, so they have. The TV show was shown here in Australia many years ago (I remember the theme: Bang, bang a Luke-y Luke!), but I’ve never heard of any of the films.
